Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 44189-01 
Regional—Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (R-PATA) 
December 2010 
 
 
 
Broadening Investor Base for Local Currency Bonds 
in ASEAN+3  
(Financed by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility) 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ABMF  –  ASEAN+3 Bond Market Forum 
  ABMI  –  Asian Bond Markets Initiative 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ASEAN  –  Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
  ASEAN+3  –  ASEAN, the People's Republic of China, Japan, and the 
    Republic of Korea 
  TA  –  technical assistance

Type  –  Regional—policy and advisory technical assistance (R-PATA) 
Targeting classification  –  Targeted intervention—ASEAN+3  
Sector (subsectors)  –  Finance (money and capital markets) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting macroeconomic stability), regional

Location impact  –  National (high); regional (high)

NOTE 
 
                                    In this report, "$" refers to US dollars.  
 
 
Head  I. Azis, Office of Regional Economic Integration (OREI) 
Deputy Head   N. Akamatsu, OREI 
   
Team leader  A. Noy Siackhachanh, Advisor, OREI 
Team member  R. Supangan, Senior Economics Officer, OREI 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian financial crisis showed that an overdependence on the banking system can 
exacerbate problems for borrowers. Having a deep and liquid bond market will offer borrowers 
the flexibility to diversify their sources of funding and provide them with an alternative for raising 
long-term  capital  to  meet  their  long-term  financing  needs.  Local  currency  bond  markets, 
therefore, help borrowers overcome the currency and maturity mismatches that contributed to 
the weaknesses of the financial system, as witnessed during the 1997–1998 Asian financial 
crisis. Based on the lessons learned from the crisis, ASEAN+31  launched the Asian Bond 
Markets Initiative (ABMI) in December 2002 to develop bond markets as an alternative source 
 
of funding to bank loans. 
2.  ASEAN+3 agreed to focus its activities on the four areas viewed as the essential building 
blocks in developing bond markets: (i) the creation of securitized debt instruments, (ii) the 
establishment of a credit guarantee and investment facility, (iii) the establishment of a regional 
settlement and clearance system, and (iv) the enhancement of credit rating practices. These 
four areas aim to boost new issuance of bonds denominated in Asian currencies by the private 
sector, improve credit information on debt issuers in the region to help inform investment 
 
decisions, and build market infrastructure to support cross-border issuance and investment. 
3.  Much has been achieved since ABMI was launched. The volume of outstanding local 
currency-denominated bonds has grown sharply from less than $1 trillion in 2001 to nearly $4.8 
trillion by the end of June 2010. By 2008, the local currency bond markets had become an 
effective alternative source of funding for governments and the corporate sector in the region to 
finance fiscal stimulus programs and meet their financing needs during the financial market 
turmoil. Twenty-five domestic rating agencies across the region were trained on international 
best practice in rating, and a handbook was provided to domestic rating agencies and regulators 
to help harmonize rating practices. A group of experts completed a study on impediments to 
cross-border bond transactions, and ASEAN+3 and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) worked 
together to establish an ASEAN+3 Bond Market Forum (ABMF) to remove these impediments. 
They are also working to set up a regional credit guarantee and investment facility to provide 
credit guarantees for issuers that seek to tap into long-term local currency debt markets within 
the region. 
4.  However, to accelerate the growth of local currency bond markets, ASEAN+3 needs to 
solve the problem of limited liquidity and a narrow investor base in those markets. While ADB 
provided regional technical assistance (TA) to explore the possibility of further developing the 
primary dealer system in the government bond markets to help boost liquidity, ASEAN+3 has 
also requested TA for assessing how the region could further broaden the investor base to 
support  the  local  currency  bond  markets.  The  design  and  monitoring  framework  is  in 
Appendix 1. The concept paper of the TA was approved on 9 February 2010.2 
 
 
 
 
                                                
1 Association of Southeast Asian Nations, the People's Republic of China, Japan, and the Republic of Korea. 
2 The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 15 April 2010.

2  
II.  ISSUES 
5  Emerging East Asia has come a long way in promoting investment in local currency 
bond markets. As of March 2010, banks held 56.6% of total outstanding government bonds in 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC), 19.1% in Indonesia, 20.4% in the Republic of Korea, 
43.4%  in  Malaysia,  34%  in  Singapore,  and  28.6%  in  Thailand.  Insurance  companies  and 
pension funds also play an increasingly important role in shaping the domestic bond markets in 
these economies. As of March 2010, insurance companies and pension funds held 9.3% of the 
total outstanding government bonds in Indonesia, 22% in the Republic of Korea, 36.2% in 
Malaysia, 66.1% in Singapore, and 39.6% in Thailand. 
6.  In the PRC, where insurance companies and pension funds hold only 5.2% of total 
outstanding government bonds, the government recently took several steps to promote investor 
diversity,  including  allowing  insurance  companies  to  invest  in  instruments  backed  by 
infrastructure projects and raising the limits for insurance companies to invest in corporate 
bonds. The PRC also continued to liberalize and promote the participation of qualified foreign-
funded financial institutions in local debt markets. 
7.  ASEAN+3 wants to broaden the investor base because investor diversity (i) leads to 
more liquid bond markets, as different investors have different risk perceptions and employ 
different trading strategies; (ii) not only enlarges the size of the market, but can also dampen 
volatility during periods of market stress; (iii) supports the efficient pooling of long-term funds 
and helps mitigate risk; and (iv) encourages innovation in products and technology, thereby 
reducing transaction costs.  
8.  Increasing investor diversity in local currency bond markets essentially means promoting 
domestic  institutional  investors—banks,  insurance  companies,  social  security  and  pension 
funds, investment funds—as well as attracting foreign investors.  
9.  The development of contractual savings vehicles is driven largely by the growth of 
liabilities, demographic changes, and welfare policies adopted by governments. Life insurance 
companies have a demand for longer-dated bonds based on their long-term liabilities. As the life 
insurance industry expands in the region, it will help grow the size of local currency bond 
markets and extend the maturity profile of benchmark government yield curves. On the other 
hand, nonlife (general) insurance firms tend to expand in line with economic growth, which helps 
boost sales growth in automobile and housing mortgages. 
10.  Pension funds in the region have significant growth potential as the authorities seek to 
meet the retirement income needs of a rapidly expanding and ageing population. Many of the 
pension systems are relatively new and evolving. The oldest pension systems are found in 
Malaysia, the Philippines, and Singapore, but these systems, too, are constantly evolving. The 
Republic of Korea’s relatively advanced system was established in 1988 and continues to 
undergo reforms. 
11.  The growth of pension funds and the liberalization of pension asset investments will help 
drive local currency bond markets. Mutual funds are popular vehicles for mobilizing retail funds. 
They  also manage  the  investments  of other  institutional  investors,  such  as  insurance  and 
pension funds. The mutual fund industry has grown and matured in several domestic markets 
and while not all funds are equally developed, some of the most advanced markets can be 
found  in  the  region.  Sound  regulation  and  pricing  practices  are  important  for  the  smooth 
functioning of investment funds, particularly during volatile periods. However, the expansion of

3
contractual savings vehicles will have to be supported in tandem with overall capital market 
development. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The impact of the TA will be the broadening of the investor base. The TA will help 
strengthen the regional financial system by deepening the bond markets and making them less 
vulnerable to sudden withdrawal of capital by a group of investors. The TA will help amend 
policies, regulations, and standards that have impeded broader participation by both domestic 
and foreign investors. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The key activities under the TA will be coordinated with the efforts of ADB’s Southeast 
Asia  Department  (SERD)  to  support  capital  market  development  within  the  Association  of 
Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). Given that broadening the investor base would also require 
promoting  the  development  of  nonbank  financial  institutions  such  as  pension  funds,  the 
insurance industry, and mutual funds, which is extensive and beyond the scope of this TA, the 
key activities under this TA will concentrate on the following:    
(i)  Comprehensive analysis of both the domestic and foreign investor bases for local 
currency  bonds  within  ASEAN,  the  PRC,  and  the  Republic  of  Korea.3 This 
includes classifying investors by type of institutions (e.g., banks, pension and 
social security funds, insurance companies, investment funds); by size and by 
rationale of their investment in local currency bonds; and by the potential for 
greater investment by these investors in ASEAN, the PRC, and the Republic of 
Korea.  The  analysis  will  also  assess  the  factors  that  favor  and  impede 
investment by these investors.  
(ii)  Recommendations, after consultation with regulators and market participants, on 
how these factors, particularly the regulations and standards, could be reformed 
and  harmonized  to  encourage  broader  participation  by  domestic  and foreign 
investors. The recommendations to facilitate foreign investment will (a) take into 
account the study and recommendations by the group of experts under ABMI on 
cross-border bond transactions, and (b) include measures for the governments to 
consider to minimize the vulnerability of their economies to sudden withdrawal of 
foreign investment in local currency bonds.  
(iii)  Comprehensive analysis of mutual funds in ASEAN, the PRC, and the Republic 
of Korea including their market size, policies, and practices to promote retail 
investments in local currency bonds. Recommendations on how the policies and 
practices in countries that actively promote retailed investment such as Thailand, 
Singapore, and the Philippines could be further improved to further broaden 
investor base and how such measures could be promoted across the region.  
(iv)  Dissemination of the recommendations to policy makers, regulators and market 
participants through workshops, as requested by members. 
                                                
3 The TA will cover only ASEAN member countries, the PRC, and the Republic of Korea because the bond market 
development in Japan is well advanced.

4  
(v)  Selection  of  key  policy  makers,  regulators,  and  market  participants  within 
ASEAN+3 that are to be invited to the ABMF. Presentation and discussion of the 
TA analyses and the recommendations on broadening the investor base at the 
ABMF,  to  encourage  adoption  of  the  recommendations  by  policymakers, 
regulators, and market participants.  
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,100,000. It will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing 
Partnership Facility,4 and administered by ADB. The cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2.    
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The  TA  will  be  administered  by  the  Office  of  Regional  Economic  Integration  in 
coordination with ASEAN+3 under the ABMI Task Force 2 work plan. The Office of Regional 
Economic Integration will also cooperate and exchange information with ADB’s Southeast Asia 
Department  on  bond  markets  in  the  ASEAN+3  economies.  The  TA  will  be  disbursed  in 
accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). The design and monitoring framework in Appendix 1 will be used to track and 
evaluate progress in implementation. The TA will be  implemented over 18 months and is 
expected to begin in April 2011 and be completed by September 2012.  
 
16.  The TA will require 21 person-months of international consulting services and 21 person-
months of national consulting services. The consultants will be engaged by ADB as individual 
consultants in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended 
from time to time). The international consultants will include a bond market specialist, who will 
also be the team leader, and a capital market specialist. National consultants with expertise in 
the  same  areas  will  be  engaged  for  the  same  length  of  time  to  provide  support  to  the 
international consultants. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3.    
 
17.  The team leader will coordinate all consultant inputs. The consultants will submit (i) an 
inception report within 1 month of TA commencement; (ii) an interim progress report, including 
analysis of factors impeding investment in local currency bonds in the markets of ASEAN, the 
PRC, and the Republic of Korea, 5 months after TA commencement; (iii) a draft final report 
12 months after TA commencement; and (iv) a final report after receiving and incorporating 
comments from ASEAN+3 members and ADB. The progress of the TA project will be discussed 
at the ABMI Task Force 2 meeting and reported to the ABMI steering meeting. The report will 
then be discussed at the ABMF to encourage adoption of its recommendations. The results and 
outputs will be shared with government officials and market participants through dissemination 
seminars and workshops, as well as with ABMI members in coordination with the Southeast 
Asia Department.   
 
 
 
 
 
                                                
4  Established by the Government of Japan.

5
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,100,000 to be financed on 
a grant basis by the Investment Climate Facilitation Fund under the Regional Cooperation and 
Integration  Financing  Partnership  Facility  for  Broadening  Investor  Base for  Local  Currency 
Bonds in ASEAN+3, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Senior bond market specialist (7 person-months). As team leader, the specialist will be 
responsible for the overall management and implementation of the technical assistance (TA), the 
timely delivery of high-quality reports, and for arranging workshops and trainings. As a bond 
market specialist, the consultant must have extensive knowledge of bond markets and at least 
15 years' practical experience working in bond markets, and must be highly knowledgeable on 
bond market regulations and practices that affect the investor base for local currency bonds.  The 
consultant  must  have  at  least  a  master’s  degree  in  finance  or  economics.  The  tasks  and 
responsibilities of the senior bond market specialist include the following:     
(i)  Take a lead role in carrying out a comprehensive assessment of the domestic 
institutional investor base for local currency bonds in the Association of Southeast 
Asian Nation (ASEAN)1, the People’s Republic of China (PRC), and the Republic of 
Korea. The assessment will include (a) the type of institutional investors in ASEAN, 
the PRC, and the Republic of Korea; (b) detailed listing of the institutional investors 
by name and by industry, (c) the size of their investment, (d) rationale for their 
investment, (e) their preference for investment, and (f) factors such as taxes and 
regulations that favor or impede their investment in local currency bonds. 
  
(ii)  Undertake a comprehensive review of investment in local currency bonds by foreign 
institutional  investors  in  ASEAN,  the  PRC,  and  the  Republic  of  Korea.  The 
assessment will include (a) the type of institutional investors in ASEAN, the PRC, 
and the Republic of Korea, (b) detailed listing of the institutional investors by name 
and by industry, (c) the size of their investment, (d) rationale for their investment, (e) 
their preference for investment, and (f) factors that favor or impede their investment 
in local currency bonds.  
 
(iii)  Recommend measures to minimize obstacles to investment by domestic and foreign 
institutional investors, particularly non-speculative foreign institutional investors. The 
recommendations  to  promote  foreign  institutional  investment  should  take  into 
account the outcome of the study under the Asian Bond Markets Initiative on cross-
border bond transactions in ASEAN+3.2  
 
(iv)  Recommend measures for the governments to minimize the vulnerability of their 
economies to sudden withdrawal of foreign investment in local currency bonds. 
 
(v)  Develop a strategy for members to broaden their institutional investor base. 
 
(vi)  Organize conferences as requested by members and prioritize issues to discuss 
and work on with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) at the ASEAN+3 Bond Market 
Forum (ABMF), to disseminate the findings of the team of consultants under the TA 
and to promote the adoption of the team’s recommendations.  
 
                                                
1 ASEAN includes Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, 
Singapore, Thailand, and Viet Nam.  
2 ASEAN, the PRC, Japan, and the Republic of Korea.

10       Appendix 3 
 
2.   Bond market specialist (4 person-months). The specialist will work with the senior bond 
market specialist to conduct the study outlined above. The division of work between the senior 
bond market specialist and the bond market specialist will be based on their individual experience 
and knowledge of bond markets in the region, and time allocated to each consultant. As a bond 
market specialist, the consultant must have at least 10 years' practical experience in bond markets, 
and must be familiar with regulations and market practices that affect the investor base for local 
currency bonds. The consultant must have at least a master’s degree in finance or economics.  
 
3.       Capital market specialist (5 person-months). The specialist will work with the senior bond 
market specialist and the bond market specialist. The specialist must be knowledgeable about 
bond markets; in particular, the specialist must have experience with mutual funds and retail 
investments. The tasks and responsibilities of the capital market specialist include the following: 
 
(i)  Undertake a comprehensive analysis of mutual funds in ASEAN, the PRC, and the 
Republic of Korea , including market size, and policies and practices to promote 
retail investment in local currency bonds; and identify and assess the policies, 
practices, and any other measures that the Philippines, Singapore, and Thailand 
have adopted to extend the investor base to retail investors. 
(ii)  Recommend how those policies and practices could be further improved to keep 
broadening the investor base, with particular attention to policies and regulations 
that  include  retail  investors  and  promote  investment  by  mutual  funds;  assess 
whether the policies and practices could be promoted across the region, and 
recommend on steps to achieve this objective. 
(iii)  Develop a strategy to promote retail investment in local currency bonds. 
(iv)  Work with the team leader to organize conferences as requested by ASEAN, the 
PRC, and the Republic of Korea  members and participate in the ABMF.  
(v)  Identify issues relating to the assessment and recommendations under this part at 
the ABMF to disseminate the findings under the TA to promote the adoption of the 
team’s recommendations.  
4.  Legal and regulatory specialist on bond markets (5 person-months). The specialist will 
work with all the above consultants. The specialist must have training in law and have at 10 years’ 
professional experience working in bond markets as a legal and regulatory expert. The specialist 
must also be familiar with regulations on mutual funds and other retail investments. The tasks and 
responsibilities of the specialist include the following: 
 
(i)  Work with the other international consultants on a comprehensive assessment of 
the legal and regulatory framework that affects foreign and domestic institutional 
investment in local currency bonds in ASEAN, the PRC, and the Republic of Korea .  
  
(ii)  Recommend  measures  to  reform  legal  and  regulatory  factors  that  impede 
investment  by  domestic  and  foreign  institutional  investors,  particularly  non-
speculative foreign institutional investors. The recommendations to promote foreign 
institutional investors should take into account the outcome of the study under the 
Asian Bond Markets Initiative on cross-border bond transactions in ASEAN+3.  
 
(iii)  Work  with  the  team  leader  to  review  the  legal  and  regulatory  frameworks  in 
ASEAN+3  that  govern  capital  inflows  and  outflows  in  the  region,  and  propose

Appendix 3  11 
recommendations to minimize the vulnerability of member economies to sudden 
withdrawal of foreign investment in local currency bonds. 
 
(iv)  Organize conferences as requested by the members and prioritize issues to discuss 
and work on with ADB at the ABMF, to disseminate the findings of the team of 
consultants under the TA and to promote adoption of the team’s recommendations.  
 
(v)  Undertake a comprehensive review of legal and regulatory frameworks governing 
mutual funds in ASEAN, the PRC, and the Republic of Korea, and specify and 
assess  the  legal  and  regulatory  policies  and  practices  that  the  Philippines, 
Singapore,  and  Thailand  have  adopted  to  extend  the  investor  base  to  retail 
investors. 
(vi)  Recommend  how  policies  and  regulations  could  be  further  improved  to  keep 
broadening the investor base, with particular attention to measures that include 
retail investment and promote mutual fund investment; assess whether the legal and 
regulatory frameworks could be promoted across the region and recommend steps 
to achieve this objective. 
(vii)  Work with the team leader to incorporate the findings and recommendations into a 
strategy component. 
(viii)  Work with the team leader to organize conferences as requested by ASEAN, the 
PRC, and the Republic of Korea members and specify issues to discuss at the 
ABMF that help disseminate the findings under the TA and promote the adoption of 
the team’s recommendations.  
 
B.  National Consultants 
5.  Bond market specialist (10 person-months) and capital market specialist (11 person-
months). The specialists will support the international consultants.
